thread.title: N.J. man takes Johnny Cash's train to 'Pawn Stars'
thread.title_full: N.J. man takes Johnny Cash's train to 'Pawn Stars'

author: Kelly Roncace | For NJ.com
title: N.J. man takes Johnny Cash's train to 'Pawn Stars'
text:
When Matt Biebel of Mullica Hill retired, he and his fiance Donna Rothstein decided to start collecting odd objects from auctions. 
Some they kept, others they sold to specialty collectors. 
One evening, while browsing the Elmer Auction in Elmer , Biebel acquired a Lionel engine and tender. 
"With it was a third-party letter," Biebel said. "The only reason I gave the letter any credence at all was because the letter was written on train collector association letterhead." 
The letter claimed that the collectible train had once belonged to Johnny Cash, legendary country singer. 
"It originally came from an estate auction in Hagerstown, Maryland, in 1974," he said. 
Biebel said he normally buys and sells trains right away, but, for some reason, he held on to this particular toy. 
"I knew what it was worth even if it hadn't belonged to Johnny Cash," he said. "Maybe it was true. Maybe it wasn't."So, Bieber began to research the train's legend and discovered a few interesting facts. 
"I went to Johnny Cash's website tour page, and saw that he had done a show in Hagerstown, Maryland, in 1974," he said. 
Further research showed that the train had been dropped off at a toy train shop in Hagerstown, Maryland, to be repaired because of water damage. MORE : 5 hair-raising reasons to see the haunted house in America's oldest penitentiary 
"He had dropped it off and the shop and never went back to get it," he said. "Johnny's family home in Tennessee was ruined by a flood." 
Biebel's son Brett Biebel lives in Las Vegas, so whenever Matt and Donna go to visit, Matt takes some collectibles along to the Pawn Stars shop near downtown. 
"They were willing to buy it in July, but wanted me to come back to film," Bieber said of the train. "On November 19 of last year, we went back out and filmed it." 
Biebel said if he hadn't been familiar with that particular train, he may not have even bought it at the auction. 
"I know a little about the train itself and figured I could turn a profit on it," he said. "But I almost threw the letter away a couple times. It kept getting in the way. Thank God I kept it." 
Biebel appeared on the season premiere of "Pawn Stars" Thursday with the train formerly owned by Johnny Cash. 
"When you walk into the store, there are three pawn brokers set up at computers," Bieber said. "There's a souvenir shop since the show has gotten so popular, but it's still a working pawn shop." 
Bieber and the pawn shop staff wheeled and dealed, and eventually settled on a nice price for the unique Lionel engine. 
"I was happy," he said. "It was a nice experience." 
Bieber appeared on "Pawn Stars" on the History Channel on Oct. 22. 
For more information, visit www.history.com/shows/pawn-stars .
